vapor_pressure¶

Created on Mon Sep 30 23:04:44 2019

@author: yoelr

class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Antoine(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Antoine equation, as described in [1]_.

Parameters

b, c (a,) – Regressed coefficients.

Notes

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

\[\log_{\text{10}} P^{\text{sat}} = A - \frac{B}{T+C}\]

Examples

Methane, coefficients from [2]_, at 100 K:

>>> f_antoine = Antoine(a=8.7687, b=395.744, c=-6.469)
>>> f_antoine.show()
Functor: Antoine(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]
 a: 8.7687
 b: 395.74
 c: -6.469
>>> f_antoine(100)
34478.367349639906

Tetrafluoromethane, coefficients from [2]_, at 180 K

>>> f_antoine = Antoine(a=8.95894, b=510.595, c=-15.95)
>>> f_antoine.show()
Functor: Antoine(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]
 a: 8.9589
 b: 510.6
 c: -15.95
>>> antoine(180)
702271.0518579542

Oxygen at 94.91 K, with coefficients from 3 in units of °C, mmHg, showing the conversion of coefficients A (mmHg to Pa) and C (°C to K)

>>> f_antoine = Antoine(6.83706+2.1249, 339.2095, 268.70-273.15)
>>> f_antoine.show()
Functor: Antoine(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]
 a: 8.962
 b: 339.21
 c: -4.45
>>> f_antoine(94.91)
162978.88655572367

References

1

Antoine, C. 1888. Tensions des Vapeurs: Nouvelle Relation Entre les Tensions et les Tempé. Compt.Rend. 107:681-684.

2

Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. 5th edition. New York: McGraw-Hill Professional, 2000.

3

Yaws, Carl L. The Yaws Handbook of Vapor Pressure: Antoine Coefficients. 1 edition. Houston, Tex: Gulf Publishing Company, 2007.

class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.TRC_Extended_Antoine(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the TRC Extended Antoine equation, as described in [1]_.

Parameters

  • Tc (None) – Critical point temperature [K].

  • a, b, c, n, E, F (to,) – Regressed coefficients.

Notes

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

\[ \begin{align}\begin{aligned}\log_{10} P^{sat} = A - \frac{B}{T + C} + 0.43429x^n + Ex^8 + Fx^{12}\\x = \max \left(\frac{T-t_o-273.15}{T_c}, 0 \right)\end{aligned}\end{align} \]

Parameters are chemical dependent, and said to be from the Thermodynamics Research Center (TRC) at Texas A&M. Coefficients for various chemicals can be found in [1]_.

Examples

Tetrafluoromethane, coefficients from [1]_, at 180 K:

>>> f_extended_antoine = TRC_Extended_Antoine(227.51, -120., 8.95894, 510.595,
...                                           -15.95, 2.41377, -93.74, 7425.9)
>>> f_extended_antoine.show()
Functor: TRC_Extended_Antoine(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]
 Tc: 227.51 K
 to: -120
 a: 8.9589
 b: 510.6
 c: -15.95
 n: 2.4138
 E: -93.74
 F: 7425.9

>>> f_extended_antoine(180.0)
706317.0898414153

References

1

Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. 5th edition. New York: McGraw-Hill Professional, 2000.

class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Wagner_McGraw(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Wagner McGraw equation, as described in [1]_.

Parameters

  • Tc (None) – Critical point temperature [K].

  • Pc (None) – Critical point pressure [Pa].

  • b, c, d (a,) – Regressed coefficients.

Notes

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

\[ \begin{align}\begin{aligned}\ln P^{sat}= \ln P_c + \frac{a\tau + b \tau^{1.5} + c\tau^3 + d\tau^6} {T_r}\\\tau = 1 - \frac{T}{T_c}\end{aligned}\end{align} \]

Warning

Pc is often treated as adjustable constant.

Examples

Methane, coefficients from [2]_, at 100 K.

>>> f_wagner_mcgraw = Wagner_McGraw(a=-6.00435, b=1.1885, c=-0.834082,
...                                 d=-1.22833, Tc=190.53, Pc=4596420.)
>>> f_wagner_mcgraw.show()
Functor: Wagner_McGraw(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]
 a: -6.0043
 b: 1.1885
 c: -0.83408
 d: -1.2283
 Tc: 190.53 K
 Pc: 4.5964e+06 Pa
>>> f_wagner_mcgraw(100)
34520.44601450496

References

1

Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. 5th edition. New York: McGraw-Hill Professional, 2000.

2

McGarry, Jack. “Correlation and Prediction of the Vapor Pressures of Pure Liquids over Large Pressure Ranges.” Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Process Design and Development 22, no. 2 (April 1, 1983): 313-22. doi:10.1021/i200021a023.

class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Wagner(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Wagner equation, as described in [1]_.

Parameters

  • Tc (None) – Critical point temperature [K].

  • Pc (None) – Critical point pressure [Pa].

  • b, c, d (a,) – Regressed coefficients.

Notes

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

\[ \begin{align}\begin{aligned}\ln P^{sat}= \ln P_c + \frac{a\tau + b \tau^{1.5} + c\tau^{2.5} + d\tau^5} {T_r}\\\tau = 1 - \frac{T}{T_c}\end{aligned}\end{align} \]

Warning

Pc is often treated as adjustable constant.

Examples

Methane, coefficients from [2]_, at 100 K.

>>> f_wagner = Wagner(190.551, 4599200, -6.02242, 1.26652, -0.5707, -1.366)
>>> f_wagner.show()
Functor: Wagner(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]
 Tc: 190.55 K
 Pc: 4.5992e+06 Pa
 a: -6.0224
 b: 1.2665
 c: -0.5707
 d: -1.366
>>> f_wagner(100)
34415.00476263708

References

1

Wagner, W. “New Vapour Pressure Measurements for Argon and Nitrogen and a New Method for Establishing Rational Vapour Pressure Equations.” Cryogenics 13, no. 8 (August 1973): 470-82. doi:10.1016/0011-2275(73)90003-9

2

Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. 5th edition. New York: McGraw-Hill Professional, 2000.

class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Boiling_Critical_Relation(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Boiling Critical Relation equation, as described in [1]_.

Parameters

  • Tb (None) – Boiling point temperature [K].

  • Tc (None) – Critical point temperature [K].

  • Pc (None) – Critical point pressure [Pa].

Notes

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

\[ \begin{align}\begin{aligned}\ln P^{sat}_r = h\left( 1 - \frac{1}{T_r} \right)\\h = T_{br} \frac{\ln(P_c/101325)}{1-T_{br}}\end{aligned}\end{align} \]

Formulation makes intuitive sense; a logarithmic form of interpolation.

Examples

Example as in [1]_ for ethylbenzene

>>> Boiling_Critical_Relation(347.2, 409.3, 617.1, 36E5)
15209.467273093938

References

1

Reid, Robert C..; Prausnitz, John M.;; Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. McGraw-Hill Companies, 1987.

class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Lee_Kesler(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Lee Kesler equation, as described in [1]_.

Parameters

  • Tc (None) – Critical point temperature [K].

  • Pc (None) – Critical point pressure [Pa].

  • ω (None) – Acentric factor [-].

Notes

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

\[ \begin{align}\begin{aligned}\ln P^{sat}_r = f^{(0)} + \omega f^{(1)}\\f^{(0)} = 5.92714-\frac{6.09648}{T_r}-1.28862\ln T_r + 0.169347T_r^6\\f^{(1)} = 15.2518-\frac{15.6875}{T_r} - 13.4721 \ln T_r + 0.43577T_r^6\end{aligned}\end{align} \]

This equation appears in [1]_ in expanded form. The reduced pressure form of the equation ensures predicted vapor pressure cannot surpass the critical pressure.

Examples

Example from [2]_; ethylbenzene at 347.2 K.

>>> Lee_Kesler(347.2, 617.1, 36E5, 0.299)
13078.694162949312

References

1

Lee, Byung Ik, and Michael G. Kesler. “A Generalized Thermodynamic Correlation Based on Three-Parameter Corresponding States.” AIChE Journal 21, no. 3 (1975): 510-527. doi:10.1002/aic.690210313.

2

Reid, Robert C..; Prausnitz, John M.;; Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. McGraw-Hill Companies, 1987.

class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Ambrose_Walton(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Ambrose Walton equation, as described in [1]_.

Parameters

  • Tc (None) – Critical point temperature [K].

  • Pc (None) – Critical point pressure [Pa].

  • ω (None) – Acentric factor [-].

Notes

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

\[ \begin{align}\begin{aligned}\ln P_r=f^{(0)}+\omega f^{(1)}+\omega^2f^{(2)}\\f^{(0)}=\frac{-5.97616\tau + 1.29874\tau^{1.5}- 0.60394\tau^{2.5}-1.06841\tau^5}{T_r}\\f^{(1)}=\frac{-5.03365\tau + 1.11505\tau^{1.5}- 5.41217\tau^{2.5}-7.46628\tau^5}{T_r}\\f^{(2)}=\frac{-0.64771\tau + 2.41539\tau^{1.5}- 4.26979\tau^{2.5}+3.25259\tau^5}{T_r}\\\tau = 1-T_{r}\end{aligned}\end{align} \]

Somewhat more accurate than the Lee_Kesler formulation.

Examples

Example from [2]_; ethylbenzene at 347.25 K.

>>> Ambrose_Walton(347.25, 617.15, 36.09E5, 0.304)
13278.878504306222

References

1

Ambrose, D., and J. Walton. “Vapour Pressures up to Their Critical Temperatures of Normal Alkanes and 1-Alkanols.” Pure and Applied Chemistry 61, no. 8 (1989): 1395-1403. doi:10.1351/pac198961081395.

2

Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. 5th edition. New York: McGraw-Hill Professional, 2000.

class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Sanjari(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Sanjari equation, as described in [1]_.

Parameters

  • Tc (None) – Critical point temperature [K].

  • Pc (None) – Critical point pressure [Pa].

  • ω (None) – Acentric factor [-].

Notes

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

\[ \begin{align}\begin{aligned}P^{sat} = P_c\exp(f^{(0)} + \omega f^{(1)} + \omega^2 f^{(2)})\\f^{(0)} = a_1 + \frac{a_2}{T_r} + a_3\ln T_r + a_4 T_r^{1.9}\\f^{(1)} = a_5 + \frac{a_6}{T_r} + a_7\ln T_r + a_8 T_r^{1.9}\\f^{(2)} = a_9 + \frac{a_{10}}{T_r} + a_{11}\ln T_r + a_{12} T_r^{1.9}\end{aligned}\end{align} \]

Although developed for refrigerants, this model should have some general predictive ability.

a[1-12] are as follows: 6.83377, -5.76051, 0.90654, -1.16906, 5.32034, -28.1460, -58.0352, 23.57466, 18.19967, 16.33839, 65.6995, -35.9739.

For a claimed fluid not included in the regression, R128, the claimed AARD was 0.428%. A re-calculation using 200 data points from 125.45 K to 343.90225 K evenly spaced by 1.09775 K as generated by NIST Webbook April 2016 produced an AARD of 0.644%. It is likely that the author’s regression used more precision in its coefficients than was shown here. Nevertheless, the function is reproduced as shown in [1]_.

For Tc=808 K, Pc=1100000 Pa, omega=1.1571, this function actually declines after 770 K.

Examples

>>> Sanjari(347.2, 617.1, 36E5, 0.299)
13651.916109552498

References

1

Sanjari, Ehsan, Mehrdad Honarmand, Hamidreza Badihi, and Ali Ghaheri. “An Accurate Generalized Model for Predict Vapor Pressure of Refrigerants.” International Journal of Refrigeration 36, no. 4 (June 2013): 1327-32. doi:10.1016/j.ijrefrig.2013.01.007.

class thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Edalat(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that calcuates saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Edalat equation, as described in [1]_.

Parameters

  • Tc (None) – Critical point temperature [K].

  • Pc (None) – Critical point pressure [Pa].

  • ω (None) – Acentric factor [-].

Notes

The vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) is given by:

\[ \begin{align}\begin{aligned}\ln(P^{sat}/P_c) = \frac{a\tau + b\tau^{1.5} + c\tau^3 + d\tau^6}{1-\tau}\\a = -6.1559 - 4.0855\omega\\b = 1.5737 - 1.0540\omega - 4.4365\times 10^{-3} d\\c = -0.8747 - 7.8874\omega\\d = \frac{1}{-0.4893 - 0.9912\omega + 3.1551\omega^2}\\\tau = 1 - \frac{T}{T_c})\end{aligned}\end{align} \]

Claimed to have a higher accuracy than the Lee-Kesler CSP relationship. [1]_ found an average error of 6.06% on 94 compounds and 1106 data points.

Examples

>>> Edalat(347.2, 617.1, 36E5, 0.299)
13461.273080743307

References

1

Edalat, M., R. B. Bozar-Jomehri, and G. A. Mansoori. “Generalized Equation Predicts Vapor Pressure of Hydrocarbons.” Oil and Gas Journal; 91:5 (February 1, 1993).
